Description: Mould-made red slipped lamp with grapes. Broken, with missing handle. Red clay oil lamp with a circular body leading out to a small v-shaped nozzle that is pierced with a circular hole at the end. The body is pierced with an off centre hole and is surrounded by a raised ring. In the centre is a bunch of grapes (?) carved in low relief. The handle is missing? There are incised rings on the underside of an almost flat base. Red-brown silt fabric with red core and tan surface, with common fine quartz, mica and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of 2nd to 4th century AD parallels for this form (copying Loeschcke 1919, Near shoulder-form VIIIa) in the British Museum aquired from 'Damenhur' and 'Alexandria' (Bailey 1988, British Museum Lamps III, Q2019-Q2068). Note many Naukratis objects were marketed through Damenhur and Alexandria in the 1800's. Loeschcke, S. 1919. Lampen aus Vindonissa. Zϋrich.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.27) (Phase 1)
